thread.title: People canceling Tesla orders over Elon Musk's link with Trump
thread.title_full: People canceling Tesla orders over Elon Musk's link with Trump

author: Amy Graff
title: People canceling Tesla orders over Elon Musk's link with Trump
text:
By Amy Graff , San Francisco Chronicle Updated 8:22 am, Wednesday, February 1, 2017 Photo: NICHOLAS KAMM, AFP/Getty Images Image 1 of / 9 Close Image 1 of 9 SpaceX CEO Elon Musk listens to US President Donald Trump speaks during a meeting with business leaders in the Roosevelt Room at the White House in Washington, DC, on January 23, 2017. SpaceX CEO Elon Musk listens to US President Donald Trump speaks during a meeting with business leaders in the Roosevelt Room at the White House in Washington, DC, on January 23, 2017. Photo: NICHOLAS KAMM, AFP/Getty Images Image 2 of 9 U.S. President Donald Trump (C) delivers opening remarks during a meeting with (L-R) Wendell Weeks of Corning, Alex Gorsky of Johnson & Johnson, Michael Dell of Dell Technologies and other business leaders and administraiton staff in the Roosevelt Room at the White House January 23, 2017 in Washington, DC. Business leaders also included Elon Musk of SpaceX, Mark Sutton of International Paper, Andrew Liveris of Dow Chemical, Marillyn Hewson of Lockheed Martin and others. less U.S. President Donald Trump (C) delivers opening remarks during a meeting with (L-R) Wendell Weeks of Corning, Alex Gorsky of Johnson & Johnson, Michael Dell of Dell Technologies and other business leaders and ... more Photo: Chip Somodevilla, Getty Images Image 3 of 9 President Donald Trump arrives to a breakfast with business leaders in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, in Washington, Jan. 23, 2017. Also pictured is, from left: Elon Musk; chief executive of SpaceX, Wendell Weeks; chief executive of Corning Inc., and Alex Gorsky; chief executive of Johnson & Johnson. less President Donald Trump arrives to a breakfast with business leaders in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, in Washington, Jan. 23, 2017. Also pictured is, from left: Elon Musk; chief executive of SpaceX, ... more Photo: DOUG MILLS, NYT Image 4 of 9 Elon Musk, chief executive officer and co-founder of Tesla Motors Inc., listens during a meeting with U.S. President-elect Donald Trump and technology leaders at Trump Tower in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, Dec. 14, 2016. Technology industry leaders met with Trump seeking to persuade a man whose presidential bid many of them opposed to avoid policies they believe would hurt their companies. "I'm here to help you folks do well," Trump told the executives as the meeting began. less Elon Musk, chief executive officer and co-founder of Tesla Motors Inc., listens during a meeting with U.S. President-elect Donald Trump and technology leaders at Trump Tower in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, ... more Photo: Albin Lohr-Jones, Bloomberg Image 5 of 9 U.S. President Donald Trump leads a meeting with invited business leaders, members of his staff and Vice President Mike Pence in the Roosevelt Room at the White House January 23, 2017 in Washington, DC. Business leaders included Elon Musk of SpaceX, Wendell Weeks of Corning, Mark Sutton of International Paper, Andrew Liveris of Dow Chemical, Alex Gorsky of Johnston & Johnson and others. less U.S. President Donald Trump leads a meeting with invited business leaders, members of his staff and Vice President Mike Pence in the Roosevelt Room at the White House January 23, 2017 in Washington, DC. ... more Photo: Chip Somodevilla, Getty Images Image 6 of 9 President Donald Trump, left center, host breakfast with business leaders in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, Monday, Jan. 23, 2017. At the meeting starting from the top going clockwise, White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus, Mark Fields from Ford Motor Company, Marillyn A. Hewson from Lockhead Martin, White House Policy Adviser Stephen Miller, Andrew Liveris from Dow Chemicals, Vice President Mike Pence, Mark Sutton from International Paper, Jeff Fettig from Whirlpool, Klaus Kleinfeld from Arconic, White House Senior Adviser Steve Bannon, left, Kevin Plank from Under Armour, Elon Musk from Telsa and SpaceX, Wendell P. Weeks from Corning, President Trump, Alex Gorsky from Johnson & Johnson, Michael S. Dell from Dell Technologies and Mario Longhi from US Steel. (AP Pho less President Donald Trump, left center, host breakfast with business leaders in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, Monday, Jan. 23, 2017. At the meeting starting from the top going clockwise, ... more Photo: Pablo Martinez Monsivais, Associated Press Image 7 of 9 President Donald Trump speaks to reporters during a breakfast with business leaders in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, in Washington, Jan. 23, 2017. From left: Stephen Bannon; counselor to the president, Kevin Plank; chief executive of Under Armour, Elon Musk; chief executive of SpaceX, Wendell Weeks; chief executive of Corning Inc., and Trump. less President Donald Trump speaks to reporters during a breakfast with business leaders in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, in Washington, Jan. 23, 2017. From left: Stephen Bannon; counselor to the president, ... more Photo: DOUG MILLS, NYT Image 8 of 9 Billionaire Elon Musk, co-founder and chief executive officer of Tesla Motors Inc., center left, and Ivanka Trump, executive vice president of development and acquisitions at Trump Organization LLC, center right, attend the Bloomberg Vanity Fair White House Correspondents' Association (WHCA) dinner afterparty in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Saturday, April 25, 2015. The 101st WHCA raises money for scholarships and honors the recipients of the organization's journalism awards. less Billionaire Elon Musk, co-founder and chief executive officer of Tesla Motors Inc., center left, and Ivanka Trump, executive vice president of development and acquisitions at Trump Organization LLC, center ... more Photo: Andrew Harrer, Bloomberg People canceling Tesla orders over Elon Musk's link with Trump 1 / 9 Back to Gallery 
Are you on the waiting list for the Tesla Model 3 sedan? 
You might have moved up a few spots in the line for the mass-market electric car that's still under development. 
Some people are claiming to have canceled their orders over Tesla CEO Elon Musk's connections with President Donald Trump and his administration. Others are saying they would if they had paid the $1,000 required to put a car on hold. . @tqbf Thanks. Cancelled my early reservation and will be donating the $1k to charity instead. Kills me as a TSLA fan but need to take stand pic.twitter.com/JW7Mjc903U — Colin Niloc (@colinniloc81) January 30, 2017 Well I haven't gotten the money back from Tesla yet, but the Twitter Police are saying i don't have the intention to donate. So I just did. — Colin Niloc (@colinniloc81) February 1, 2017 If I had a Tesla on order I would cancel it."Elon Musk: I'm Trump's voice of reason - BBC News" https://t.co/WImccpa9Lo — Joseph Lord (@jl_hfl) January 27, 2017 
Some are also saying that Musk associating with Trump shouldn't be protested because it's good to have dissenting voices in places of power. Part of me wants to cancel my #TESLA order.But the rest replies "if we keep good people off #Trump 's staff, what would he be left with?" — Ric Bretschneider (@ricbret) January 29, 2017 
While Musk has described Mr Trump as "probably not the right guy" to run the United States, he agreed to serve on Trump's Strategic & Policy Forum and a manufacturing council. 
"The more voices of reason that the President hears, the better," he has said . 
Musk praised Trump's choice for Secretary of State and says he agrees with Rex Tillerson's support for a carbon tax. And he took to Twitter to ask his followers for suggestions on ways to amend the immigration order. Latest from the SFGATE homepage: Click below for the top news from around the Bay Area and beyond. Sign up for our newsletters to be the first to learn about breaking news and more. Go to 'Sign In' and 'Manage Profile' at the top of the page. TRUMP'S PRESIDENCY
